A ''Forbes'' magazine article described in 2013 how Isabel dos Santos acquired her wealth by taking stakes in companies doing business in Angola, suggesting that her wealth comes almost entirely from her family's power and connections.<ref name=DolanForbes>{{cite news|work=Forbes|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/kerryadolan/2013/08/14/how-isabel-dos-santos-took-the-short-route-to-become-africas-richest-woman/|title=Daddy's Girl: How An African 'Princess' Banked $3 Billion In A Country Living On $2 Per Day|first=Kerry A. |last=Dolan|date=August 14, 2013|accessdate=March 16, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://economico.sapo.pt/noticias/isabel-dos-santos-desmente-acusacoes-de-enriquecimento-ilicito-feitas-pela-forbes_175473.html|title=Isabel dos Santos desmente acusações de enriquecimento ilícito feitas pela Forbes|work=Económico}}</ref> In November 2015, the [[BBC]] named Isabel dos Santos as one of the 100 most influential women in the world.<ref>[https://www.bbc.com/news/world-34745739 BBC 100 Women 2015: Who is on the list?] BBC, 17 November 2015</ref>
== Family and education == Isabel dos Santos was born in [[Baku]], [[Azerbaijan Soviet Socialist Republic|Azerbaijan SSR]],<ref name="auto"/> the oldest daughter of Angola's former President [[José Eduardo dos Santos]] and his first wife, the Russian-born Tatiana Kukanova, whom he met while studying in the [[Soviet Union|Soviet]] republic of [[Azerbaijan]].<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/jan/25/isobel-dos-santos-africas-first-female-billionaire The Guardian: "Isabel dos Santos, dubbed 'princess', named Africa's first female billionaire" by David Smith] January 25, 2013</ref><ref>[http://mg.co.za/article/2012-11-02-00-angola-whos-who-in-the-palace Mail & Guardian (Zambia): "Angola: Who's who in the palace?" by Louise Redvers] November 2, 2012</ref><ref>[http://www.theaustralian.com.au/news/breaking-news/angolan-africas-first-woman-billionaire/story-fn3dxix6-1226561407045 The Australian: "Angolan Africa's first woman billionaire"] January 25, 2013</ref> Her father's parents came from [[São Tomé and Príncipe]].<ref name=MPLA>[http://mpla-angola.org/opresidente.php#bio Biography at MPLA website] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110122000811/http://www.mpla-angola.org/opresidente.php |date=2011-01-22 }} {{pt icon}}</ref><ref>[http://mg.co.za/article/2012-11-02-00-angola-whos-who-in-the-palace Mail & Guardian: "Angola: Who's who in the palace?" by Louise Redvers] November 02, 2012</ref> She attended the all girls boarding school in Kent, [[Cobham Hall]]. She studied [[electrical engineering]]<ref>Celso Filipe, [https://www.jornaldenegocios.pt/home.php?template=SHOWNEWS_V2&id=345996 Report about Isabel dos Santos on Negócios Online], December 2008</ref> at [[King's College London|King's College]] in London.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-21184854|title=Isabel dos Santos: 'First African female billionaire'|work=BBC News}}</ref> There she met her husband from [[Zaire]] (now [[Democratic Republic of the Congo]]), [[Sindika Dokolo]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dokolo.com/Sa%20famille.html|title=La Famille Dokolo : Ndona Tuluka - Nzolantima - Hanne - Manzanza - Sindika - Luzolo|publisher=}}</ref> a son of a millionaire from [[Kinshasa]] and his [[Denmark|Danish]] wife.<ref>{{cite web|title=Augustin Dokolo, an African entrepreneur|url=http://www.dokolo.com/Biography.html|accessdate=14 March 2013}}</ref>
== Career == In the past 20 years Isabel dos Santos has held management positions in a number of companies listed on European stock exchanges. Isabel dos Santos returned from [[London]] in the early 1990s to join her father in [[Luanda]] and started working as a project manager engineer for ''Urbana 2000'', a subsidiary of Jembas Group, that had won a contract to clean and disinfect the city.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.publico.pt/economia/noticia/isabel-dos-santos-o-rosto-de-angola-1300051|title=Isabel dos Santos: o rosto de Angola|language=Portuguese|date=July 20, 2007|publisher=Público|accessdate=January 8, 2016}}</ref> Following that, she set up a trucking business. The widespread use of walkie-talkie technology paved the way for her subsequent foray into telecoms.<ref name="ReferenceA">{{cite web|url=http://www.ft.com/intl/cms/s/2/6ffd2edc-955e-11e2-a4fa-00144feabdc0.html#axzz2PCUD46D8|title=Lunch with the FT: Isabel dos Santos|work=Financial Times}}</ref> In 1997, she started her first business, opening the ''Miami Beach Club'',<ref>{{cite web|url=http://theafricaneconomist.com/meet-the-forbes-second-richest-african-woman-isabel-dos-santos/#.VpADUvmLTIU|title=Meet The Forbes Second Richest African Woman: Isabel dos Santos|date=December 4, 2012|publisher=The African Economist|accessdate=January 8, 2016}}</ref> one of the first night clubs and beach restaurants on the [[Ilha de Luanda|Luanda Island]]. Over a period of nearly 20 years she expanded her business interests, leading to the creation of several holdings, in Angola and mostly abroad, making substantial investments in high-profile entreprises, especially in Portugal.<ref>[https://economico.sapo.pt/noticias/isabel-dos-santos-reforca-em-portugal-com-entrada-na-zon_77174.html Isabel dos Santos reforça em Portugal com entrada na Zon] Diário Económico, 21 December 2009 (pt)</ref><ref>[https://www.jornaldenegocios.pt/home.php?template=SHOWNEWS_V2&id=499767 Isabel dos Santos é a 18ª figura mais poderosa da economia portuguesa] Jornal de Negócios, 4 August 2011 (pt)</ref> In June 2016, she was appointed by President dos Santos as chairwoman of [[Sonangol Group|Sonangol]], the Angolan state oil company.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://mgafrica.com/article/2016-06-03-all-in-the-family-angola-president-picks-eldest-daughter-to-head-state-oil-firm-western-firms-scramble-for-contract|title=All in the family: Angola president picks eldest daughter to head state oil firm, western firms scramble for contracts|date=2016-06-03|work=MG Africa|access-date=2017-03-14|language=en}}</ref> The controversial appointment in the wake of similar appointments of children of the president to key posts led to speculation in the Angolan media in March 2017 that Isabel dos Santos would leave Sonangol, which proved to be unfounded.<ref>See e.g. Novo Jornal / Luanda, 10/03/2017</ref>
=== Investments in Portugal === Since 2008 she has had interests in [[telecommunications]], [[Mass media|media]], [[retail]], [[finance]] and the [[energy industry]], both in Angola and in [[Portugal]]. In addition to her commercial interest in oil and diamonds, Isabel dos Santos also owns shares in the Angola cement company [[Nova Cimangola]]. Jadeium, a company held by Isabel dos Santos, acquired 4.918% of ZON Multimedia shares from Spain’s [[Telefonica]].<ref>[http://web3.cmvm.pt/sdi2004/emitentes/docs/PQ39531.pdf] by CMVM</ref><ref>[http://web3.cmvm.pt/sdi2004/emitentes/docs/PQ39584.pdf ] by CMVM</ref>
Through the [[Netherlands]]-based ''Unitel International Holdings BV'',<ref name="ANNOUNCEMENT">[http://web3.cmvm.pt/sdi2004/emitentes/docs/FR42703.pdf ANNOUNCEMENT], CMVM Official website 14.12.2012</ref> a company controlled by Isabel dos Santos,<ref>[http://www.portugaldailyview.com/whats-new/isabel-dos-santos-reinforces-her-presence-in-portuguese-firms Angola: Isabel dos Santos reinforces her presence in Portuguese firms] ''Portugaldailyview.com'', 9 May 2012</ref><ref>[http://www.millenniumbcp.pt/multimedia/archive/00422/ZON_422000a.pdf Millennium investment banking: Kento member of Banco BIC Português,<ref>[http://www.bancobic.pt/eportal/v10/PT/aspx/oBpn/governo/modelogov/index.aspx Banco BIC Português] Official website</ref> which recently acquired Banco Português de Negócios, a nationalized bank.<ref>[https://www.forbes.com/profile/isabel-dos-santos/ Isabel dos Santos profile] in Forbes</ref>
Since November 2012 Isabel dos Santos is a non-executive board member of ZON.<ref>[http://www.ionline.pt/dinheiro/isabel-dos-santos-integra-administracao-da-zon ''Isabel dos Santos integra administração da [[NOS (Portuguese media company)|Zon]] by LUSA Press agency''] ionline.pt. Retrieved 7 July 2018 (portugueses)</ref> In December 2012, Isabel dos Santos announced the invitation for a merger of ZON with Sonaecom, proved in March 2013 by the General Assembly.<ref name="ANNOUNCEMENT"/> Eight months later, after the green light from the Competition Authority, the merger of the two companies was formalized on August 27, 2013, with the transfer to ZOPT, a special purpose vehicle created to advance the operation which became the owner of more 50% of the capital of the new group, the shares that Isabel dos Santos and Sonaecom hold on Zon and Optimus respectively. There was a capital increase of ZOPT through contribution in kind from 50 to 716 million euros, while Sonaecom subscribed 358 million shares of the company, by delivering 81.8% of its stake in Optimus. The Angolan businesswoman, on her turn, subscribed exactly the same number of shares of ZOPT, through her holdings Kento and [[Unitel (Angola)|Unitel]] International, delivering 28.8% of the stake in ZON.<ref>[http://web3.cmvm.pt/sdi2004/emitentes/docs/PQ46594.pdf] by CMVM</ref><ref>[http://web3.cmvm.pt/sdi2004/emitentes/docs/ODRA46598.pdf] by CMVM</ref><ref>[http://web3.cmvm.pt/sdi2004/emitentes/docs/TRAN46596.pdf] by CMVM</ref><ref>[http://web3.cmvm.pt/sdi2004/emitentes/docs/ODRA46592.pdf] by CMVM</ref> With this transfer of shareholdings in Optimus and Zon, Sonaecom and Isabel dos Santos became holders of over 50% stake in the merged company: Zon Optimus SGPS. On this occasion, a new strategy for the company was announced by Isabel dos Santos, with a multimarket vision.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.portugaleconomyprobe.pt/library/we-suggest/news-a-facts/8289-press-review-merger-of-zon-multimedia-and-optimus-approved-in-portugal-great-potential-for-expansion|title=Optimus, Zon merger brings potential for expansion - Dos Santos|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fibra.pt/empresas/6779-zonoptimus-merger-isabel-dos-santos-the-strategy-of-the-new-company-will-be-open-to-new-geographies.html]|title=Isabel dos Santos The strategy of the new company will be open to new geographies|publisher=}}</ref> On October 1, 2013, Isabel dos Santos attended the first General Assembly of Zon Optimus.<ref>[https://www.sabado.pt/ultima-hora/detalhe/Isabel-dos-Santos-comparece-na-AG-da-Zon-Optimus ''Isabel dos Santos comparece na AG da Zon Optimus''] sabado.pt. Retrieved 7 July 2018 (portuguese)</ref> Isabel dos Santos’ investments in Portugal are in listed companies, which are therefore subject to official supervision of the Portuguese Securities Market Commission (CMVM).<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cmvm.pt/en/a%20cmvm/apresentacao/pages/apresentacao.aspx |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2012-12-12 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130331031857/http://www.cmvm.pt/en/a%20cmvm/apresentacao/pages/apresentacao.aspx |archivedate=2013-03-31 |df= }} CMVM</ref>
In November 2014, Isabel dos Santos launched a takeover bid for [[Portugal Telecom]], SGPS, S.A., valuing the firm’s shares at €1.35 a share, in what was seen as a rival bid to a previous €7 billion offer from [[Altice (company)|Altice]]. Though the offer made by Altice is on PT Portugal, not on PT SGPS.<ref>[https://www.reuters.com/article/2014/11/09/us-portugal-nos-pt-idUSKCN0IT0T520141109 NOS shareholder bids for Portugal Telecom shares] Reuters, 09 November 2014</ref> On December 1, 2014, the Angolan businesswoman formally registered her offer at the [[Portuguese Securities Market Commission]] (Comissão do Mercado de Valores Mobiliários, CMVM, in Portuguese).<ref>[https://www.reuters.com/article/2014/12/01/portugal-telecom-santos-idUSL6N0TI42Q20141201 Dos Santos launches bid for Portugal Telecom SGPS] Reuters, 01 December 2014</ref>
In January 2017 [[Unitel (Angola)|Unitel]], led by Isabel dos Santos, officialized the purchase of 2% of Banco Fomento de Angola (BFA bank) from BPI for 28 million euros and now controls 51.9% of the bank's capital.<ref>[https://www.bloomberg.com/research/stocks/private/snapshot.asp?privcapId=10946343 BFA Announces Board Changes] Bloomberg, January 2017</ref> The operation was approved by sector regulators, namely the [[National Bank of Angola]] (BNA) in December 2016. In February 2017 Isabel dos Santos decides to sell her position in Banco BPI, following the takeover bid launched by [[CaixaBank]]. All in all, Isabel dos Santos arrived in 2009, stepped out in 2017 and won more than 80 million euros: Santos’ capital gain comes not only from the sale of the 18.5% holding on BPI, but also from the dividends from 2008 and 2009, worth around 12.6 million euros.<ref>[http://econews.pt/2017/02/14/isabel-dos-santos-steps-out-of-bpi-with-80-million Isabel dos Santos steps out of BPI with 80 million] ECO News, 14 February 2017</ref>
=== Investments in Angola === With 51% control of ''Condis'', Isabel dos Santos signed a joint partnership with the Portuguese [[Sonae]] group in April 2011 for the development and operation of a retail trading company in Angola. The entry in Angola by the Portuguese group led by [[Paulo de Azevedo]] will be performed by the [[Modelo Continente|Continente (Angola)]], which plans to open the first supermarket by 2013 in Angola.<ref>[http://www.portugalglobal.pt/PT/PortugalNews/Paginas/NewDetail.aspx?newId=%7BE0DA500A-CE60-4924-ADA7-8FAEE6AB3411%7D Portuguese group Sonae authorised to open hypermarkets in Angola] Aicep Portugal Global, retrieved 27 December 2011</ref>
=== Focus on telecommunications === She created [[Unitel (Angola)|Unitel]] in partnership with [[Portugal Telecom]], after a tender process she considered fair.<ref name="ReferenceA"/> Also through Unitel International Holding, a platform for Unitel investments where Portugal Telecom has no presence, she acquired the mobile operator T+, in Cape Verde and gained the license for the establishment of the second telecom operator in São Tomé and Príncipe.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.portalangop.co.ao/motix/pt_pt/noticias/ciencia-e-tecnologia/2013/2/13/Unitel-Internacional-assina-contrato-para-ser-segunda-operadora-Sao-Tome-Principe,1f36edd7-2279-4dc4-a9ed-fe5b29bf157c.html|title=Unitel Internacional assina contrato para ser segunda operadora em São Tomé e Príncipe|work=ANGOP}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.telecompaper.com/news/unitel-takes-over-control-of-t-in-cape-verde--903089|title=Unitel takes over control of T+ in Cape Verde|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.africatelecomit.com/unitel-to-become-second-operator-in-sao-tome-principe/|title=Africa Telecom & IT – Unitel to become second operator in Sao Tome & Principe|publisher=}}</ref> Under this investment Isabel dos Santos announced during a visit to São Tomé and Príncipe that Unitel will invest in education in the country to train engineers, managers and other technicians and also focus on job creation.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.macauhub.com.mo/en/2013/05/31/unitel-stp-to-start-operating-in-sao-tome-and-principe-this-year|title=Unitel STP to start operating in Sao Tome and Principe this year|work=Macauhub English}}</ref>
By 2015, Isabel dos Santos owned a share of satellite-TV operator ZAP, that had in December 2013 acquired the rights to distribute ''Forbes'' in a number of Portuguese speaking countries, namely Portugal, Angola and Mozambique. It had been announced that most of the content would be produced by a local team, complemented by content for the North American edition, therefore potentially allowing influence on ''Forbes'' content. It was initially planned that the first edition of the Portuguese language ''Forbes'' would be published during the second quarter of 2014. <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.publico.pt/economia/noticia/forbes-chega-este-ano-a-portugal-e-africa-pela-mao-de-isabel-dos-santos-1699597|title=Forbes chega este ano a Portugal e África, pela mão de Isabel dos Santos|author=PÚBLICO|work=PÚBLICO}}</ref>
=== Holdings === Holdings of Isabel dos Santos in the recent years:<ref>[http://www.dinheirovivo.pt/Mercados/Artigo/CIECO045020.html?page=2 Os negócios de Isabel dos Santos em Portugal] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140222200703/http://www.dinheirovivo.pt/Mercados/Artigo/CIECO045020.html?page=2 |date=2014-02-22 }} Dinheiro Vivo Online, 9 May 2012 (pt)</ref><ref>[http://www.clipquick.com/Files/Imprensa/2012/08-01/0/1_1870377_7E1C4A2D8B3731959B5EFFAA1CAC6C0A.pdf A Angolana mais rica de Portugal, English: ''The most rich Angolan in Portugal''] clipquick.com, 1 August 2012 (pt)</ref>
* Trans Africa Investment Services, a [[Gibraltar]] based vehicle founded together with her mother for the diamond business * Unitel International Holdings B.V.: change of name of Kento and Jadeium, based in [[Amsterdam]], company-vehicle for Isabel dos Santos’ investment in telecommunications * Santoro Finance: company-vehicle for Isabel dos Santos’ investment in Banco BPI based in [[Lisbon]] * Esperaza Holding B.V.: based in [[Amsterdam]], energy, oil etc. * Condis: a retail business based in Luanda

'''Jean Van Milders''' (13 November 1924 – 20 June 2011<ref>[http://www.humo.be/humo-dossiers/32102/jean-van-milders-overleden. Artikel over zijn overlijden in [[Humo]]], 20 June 2011</ref>) was a Belgian businessman and the president of soccer team [[AA Gent]] for ten years.
==Business career== Born in [[Geel]], Van Milders was a talented entrepreneur. He managed to develop the Brewery Van Milders situated in Geel, which he had inherited together with his brothers from his parents, to a sound company and he introduced the abbey beer Tongerlo. 1970, The brothers sold their brewery and started bottling [[Coca-Cola]]. As from 1976, they were catering Carestel-road restaurants.
Van Milders sometimes proclaimed very strange expressions about his entrepreneurial management. A good one-liner of his was: "As a child, what did we know about money? Nothing at all! And now, I've got grandchildren playing with their money on the stock markets."
==President of AA Gent== As from July 1988 to 1998, Van Milders was he president of [[AA Gent]]. This soccer team was just degraded out of [[ Belgian First Division]] and the team had a heavy burden. Van Milders used his rich bank account to help the team financially.
In soccer, this meant a large difference at AA Gent. He transferred some well-known players to the team, making the way of playing more attractive. After a number of years, the team played European games again. In 1992, AA Gent reached the quarter finals of the [[UEFA Cup]]. This was the best European result under his guidance. In the Belgian competition, it did not work out so well the next years, but the foundations of the successes were laid. Those were achieved under his successor [[Ivan De Witte]].
Van Milders died in [[Knokke-Heist]].
==References== {{Reflist}} *{{cite web|url=http://www.kaagent.be|title=KAA Gent|publisher=kaagent.be|accessdate=2015-07-25}}

'''Johnny Reklai''' (July 1, 1948 – March 11, 2007) was a [[Palau]]an businessman and [[politician]]. At the time of his death he was serving as the president of the [[Senate of Palau]]. He was succeeded in that office by [[Surangel S. Whipps]], and his seat was filled by [[Hokkons Baules]].

{{ExcessiveCitations|date=May 2017}} {{Infobox person |name = Joseph Sanberg |image = |birth_date = {{birth date and age|1979|7|12}} |birth_place = [[Southern California]], [[United States|U.S.]] |death_date = |death_place = |education = [[Harvard University]] {{small|([[Bachelor of Arts|BA]])}} |occupation = Entrepreneur and investor |website = {{url|joesanberg.com}} }} '''Joseph N. Sanberg''' is an American entrepreneur and investor. He is the founder of CalEITC4Me, a statewide outreach program in California that helps low-income families claim the state and federal earned income tax credits. He is the Co-Founder and Chair of the Board of Advisors for Aspiration.com, an online banking and investing firm known for its socially conscious products and "Pay What Is Fair" business model.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.politico.com/tipsheets/california-playbook/2017/01/rendon-orders-assembly-staffing-overhaul-brown-bemoans-political-language-lee-boycotting-trump-inauguration-218221|title=RENDON orders Assembly staffing overhaul -- BROWN bemoans ‘political language’ -- LEE boycotting TRUMP inauguration|website=POLITICO}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ocregister.com/2016/12/24/most-influential-2016-joseph-sanberg-connects-the-working-poor-to-californias-earned-income-tax-credit/|title=Most Influential 2016: Joseph Sanberg connects the working poor to California’s earned income tax credit – Orange County Register|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ozy.com/2016/democrats-turn-to-an-unlikely-ally-big-business/74410|title=The Democratic Party’s Next Move: Making Friends with Big Business|first=Nick|last=Fouriezos|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/darren-aronofsky-joins-sierra-club-901701|title=Darren Aronofsky Joins Sierra Club Foundation Board of Directors|publisher=}}</ref><ref>http://www.modernluxury.com/orange-county/story/no-average-joe</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/devinthorpe/2015/08/25/impact-investor-credits-faith-in-god-for-success/#6cd656b3aada|title=Impact Investor Credits 'Faith In God' For Success|first=Devin|last=Thorpe|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.startupsense.net/blog/ep-141-interview-with-joseph-sanberg-founder-of-aspiration|title=Ep 141: Interview with Joseph Sanberg, founder of Aspiration|website=Ep 141: Interview with Joseph Sanberg, founder of Aspiration}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.yezminthomas.com/tag/joseph-n-sanberg/|title=Joseph N. Sanberg Archives - One Take Podcast, with Yezmin Thomas|website=One Take Podcast, with Yezmin Thomas}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://medium.com/@SimpleInnovativ/fireside-chat-with-aspiration-co-founder-and-chair-of-the-board-of-advisors-joseph-sanberg-e78554daa73d|title=Fireside Chat with Aspiration Co-Founder and Chair of the Board of Advisors, Joseph Sanberg|date=5 July 2016|publisher=}}</ref>
==Education== Born and raised in Southern California, Sanberg went to the [[Anaheim]] [[Servite High School]] and earned his A.B., Magna Cum Laude, in Government from [[Harvard University]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://alumni.harvard.edu/stories/two-harvard-entrepreneurs-aspire-to-do-well-doing-good|title=Two Harvard Friends Aspire to Do Well by Doing Good - Stories - Harvard Alumni|publisher=}}</ref> He later created an International Leadership Program at the same school that gave students learning Mandarin scholarships to visit China.<ref name="josephnsanberg.com">{{cite web|url=http://josephnsanberg.com/|title=Joseph Sanberg – Harnessing the power of innovation to make people’s lives better|website=josephnsanberg.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://m.youtube.com/watch?v=S_KNiQ63jtw|title=Joe Sanberg Video 2|first=|last=MikeZunigaFilms|date=9 February 2017|publisher=|via=YouTube}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://m.youtube.com/watch?t=43s&v=67z4WflFU1Q|title=Joseph Sanberg Seminar: "We Have to Actually Fix Things!"|first=|last=UCR School of Public Policy|date=22 February 2017|publisher=|via=YouTube}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://m.youtube.com/watch?v=RoGPWvTKNyQ|title=Joseph Sanberg: A Grandfather's Legacy|first=|last=Univ. of California, Riverside|date=4 October 2016|publisher=|via=YouTube}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://m.youtube.com/watch?v=14sUMs7sYsU|title=Joseph Sanberg - Aspen Institute|first=|last=Golden State Opportunity Foundation|date=27 January 2017|publisher=|via=YouTube}}</ref>
==Career== Sanberg co-founded Aspiration.com, an online financial company. Aspiration enables customers to choose their own fee levels on checking and investment accounts, and offers managed funds that are 100% fossil free.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://aspiration.com|title=Aspiration - Do Well. Do Good.|website=Aspiration|access-date=2017-05-18}}</ref>
Sanberg is a founding investor in Blue Apron, a home meal delivery service, and serves on the boards of companies like Bright Funds, which helps people support their charitable causes, and IVY.com, a social university.<ref name="josephnsanberg.com"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.publicnewsservice.org/2017-01-06/social-justice/nevada-progressive-groups-rally-the-faithful-this-weekend/a55793-1|title=Nevada Progressive Groups Rally the Faithful This Weekend|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sacbee.com/opinion/opn-columns-blogs/dan-morain/article46581765.html|title=Dan Morain: Joe tries to show one guy can make a difference|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://medium.com/@JosephNSanberg/sustainable-investing-is-smartest-7a643207cd81|title=Sustainable Investing is Smartest|date=5 January 2016|publisher=}}</ref>
Sanberg holds positions at multiple public service organizations including serving on the Board of Governors at the [http://www.jeffersonawards.org/ Jefferson Awards Foundation], an organization that engages over a million youth in volunteer programs and public service annually.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.jeffersonawards.org/about/|title=Jefferson Awards Foundation - About Us|work=Jefferson Awards Foundation|access-date=2017-05-17|language=en-US}}</ref> Sanberg also serves on the Board of Advisors of the [[University of California]], Riverside School of Public Policy.<ref name="josephnsanberg.com"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sacbee.com/news/politics-government/capitol-alert/article134357089.html|title=California wants to give a tax credit to the working poor but some people aren’t signing up|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://jewishjournal.com/cover_story/182589/|title=Joseph Sanberg: A one-man army against poverty — Jewish Journal|date=17 February 2016|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://tonyloyd.com/026/|title=026, Joseph Sanberg, Aspiration - Build Trust by Doing Good - Tony Loyd|website=tonyloyd.com}}</ref>
Sanberg was called "the spark" for his leadership in 2015 toward California launching an Earned Income Tax Credit (EITC). To support the California EITC, he founded a statewide outreach program called CalEITC4Me that is administered by Golden State Opportunity Foundation, which conducts research, analysis, public information and education programs with the aim of creating economic security for Californians.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.politico.com/tipsheets/california-playbook/2015/12/politico-california-playbook-presented-by-chevron-horror-in-san-bernardino-nurses-for-newsom-new-ppic-poll-211572|title=POLITICO California Playbook, presented by Chevron: HORROR IN SAN BERNARDINO -- NURSES for Newsom -- NEW PPIC poll|website=POLITICO}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://theievoice.com/creating-a-current-for-change-joe-sanbergs-golden-state-opportunity/|title=Creating a Current for Change: Joe Sanberg’s Golden State Opportunity {{!}} VOICE|date=2016-01-07|work=VOICE|access-date=2017-05-17|language=en-US}}</ref> CalEITC4Me<ref>{{cite web|url=https://m.youtube.com/watch?v=bJZtiwv4034|title=CalEITC4Me San Diego: Closing Remarks|first=|last=CalEITC4Me|date=26 January 2016|publisher=|via=YouTube}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://m.youtube.com/watch?v=9Hs8sJTEr0M|title=LA CalEITC Awareness Week Press tax preparation services. <ref>{{cite web|url=http://capitalandmain.com/getting-the-word-about-the-earned-income-tax-credit-to-working-families-0213|title=Getting the Word About the Earned Income Tax Credit to Working Families – Capital & Main|website=capitalandmain.com}}</ref><ref name="josephnsanberg.com"/><ref>{{cite Register|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ocregister.com/2016/02/22/a-man-a-tax-credit-and-a-mission-to-end-poverty-how-a-laguna-beach-millionaire-is-helping-spread-a-four-letter-word/|title=A man, a tax credit, and a mission to end poverty: How a Laguna Beach millionaire is helping spread a four-letter word – Orange County Register|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite workers’|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mercurynews.com/2016/06/09/mercury-news-editorial-california-must-reward-low-income-workers/|title=Mercury News editorial: California must page.title: Maternity leave and the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development

revision.text:
Forty-one countries have some form of paid [[parental leave]], and the [[Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development]] provides data from these countries about leave length, average pay rate and full-rate equivalent.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://www.oecd.org/els/family/database.htm|title=OECD Family Database - OECD|website=www.oecd.org|access-date=2016-11-10}}</ref> Not all countries provide mothers with a pay rate equal to what they would have received if the absence had not occurred.
Rate of basic pay can be defined as fixed pay received through [[minimum wage law]] or an administratively-determined wage.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.opm.gov/faqs/QA.aspx?fid=e64d74ab-20a3-484c-8682-d2a2b46c22da&pid=adb00212-6ce3-4642-8e6f-95ab709f0d8a|title=What is the definition of rate of basic pay for the purpose of paying a... - OPM.gov|website=U.S. Office of Personnel Management|access-date=2016-11-10}}</ref> Organizations and activists are working to inform, persuade and change pay-rate laws. Women in the workforce are at a disadvantage; regardless of legislation, a global [[gender pay gap]] is still visible.<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Blau |first=Francine D. |last2=Kahn |first2=Lawrence M. |year=2003 |title=Understanding International Differences in the Gender Pay Gap |journal=Journal of Labor Economics |volume=21 |issue=1 |pages=106–144 |doi=10.1086/344125 }}</ref> The OECD is a primary supplier of research and data pertaining to parental-leave rights.<ref name=":0" />
== Background == Paid maternity leave is important for women to take time away from work to bond with a child without financial pressures. Of the 193 [[United Nations]] countries, only a handful do not have a paid-parental-leave policy: [[New Guinea]], [[Suriname]], the [[United States]] and a few South [[Pacific Ocean|Pacific]] [[Island country|island nation]]s.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/2016/10/06/495839588/countries-around-the-world-beat-the-u-s-on-paid-parental-leave|title=Countries Around The World Beat The U.S. On Paid Parental Leave|publisher=}}</ref> The international history dates back to the 1970s, with countries such as Iraq granting full pay for women. By the 1980s, [[Great Britain]] was at the point of giving women benefits but did not specify a pay rate.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/life-style/health-and-families/features/the-timeline-maternity-leave-2113236.html|title=The Timeline: Maternity leave|date=2010-10-22|newspaper=The Independent|language=en-GB|access-date=2016-11-14}}</ref> The history of pay rates is limited and not well-recorded, except by the OECD.
== {{anchor|Different Kinds of Leave}}Types of leave == Maternity leave varies by country, with most developed countries having at least one set type of maternity leave. Most maternity leaves include a length of time to take off, with some form of pay. The following countries grouped by pay rate.
=== United Kingdom === In the [[United Kingdom]] maternity-leave pay is known as Statutory Maternity Pay (SMP), which can cover up to 39 weeks of maternity leave. A woman can expect to earn 90 percent of her weekly earnings for the first six weeks of maternity leave; after that, the rate decreases.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.gov.uk/maternity-pay-leave/pay|title=Maternity pay and leave - GOV.UK|website=www.gov.uk|access-date=2016-12-01}}</ref>
=== Australia, Canada, and New Zealand === In Australia, women can receive up to 18 weeks minimum-wage from the government; if an employer offers paid leave, a mother can receive that as well. In Canada, a woman can receive 17 weeks of maternity leave: two weeks before giving birth and 15 weeks afterwards. The two weeks before birth are unpaid.<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=https://www.oecd.org/els/family/PF2_5_Trends_in_leave_entitlements_around_childbirth_Annex.pdf|title=Annex: Detail of Change in Parental by Country|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=|access-date=2016-12-07}}</ref> In New Zealand, primary leave is 18 weeks of paid leave; special leave covers 10 days (spread out) for appointments or unpaid illness.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.employment.govt.nz/leave-and-holidays/parental-leave/types-of-parental-leave/|title=Types of parental leave » Employment|website=www.employment.govt.nz|access-date=2016-12-01}}</ref>
=== Denmark, Greece, and Switzerland === In Denmark, a woman can receive 35 or 46 weeks of paid leave; the 35-week pay leave may be spread over 46 weeks.<ref name=":1" /> Women in Greece must be insured to receive maternity benefits, which include 56 days before giving birth and 63 days afterwards. To receive the benefits a woman must stop working for 56 days. If she does not take 56 days off, the woman must add the days after giving birth to be paid.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.angloinfo.com/how-to/greece/healthcare/pregnancy-birth/benefits|title=Maternity and Birth Benefits - Greece - Angloinfo|newspaper=Angloinfo|access-date=2016-12-08}}</ref> In Switzerland, a woman is guaranteed up to 14 weeks (a minimum of 8 weeks) of paid leave after giving birth. She is paid 80 percent of her previous wage, with a daily maximum.<ref name=":1" />
=== {{anchor|Iceland, Japan, Turkey, and Slovak Republic}}Iceland, Japan, Turkey and Slovakia === Icelandic women receive 13 weeks of paid maternity leave (with an additional shared 13 weeks), with a ceiling of [[Icelandic króna|ISK]]370,000 per month. Japan allows 14 weeks if the woman is enrolled in the Employees' Health Insurance system. The leave can be taken by both parents in one absence period. There is a minimum payment of [[Japanese yen|¥]]46,230 per month and a maximum monthly payment of ¥285,420. Sixteen weeks of maternity leave are on the condition that the employee was employed for 236 weeks by the 15th week before the first week of leave. There is no ceiling on payments for the first six weeks. [[Slovakia]] grants leave until the child's third birthday as a family entitlement, with a monthly benefit of €203.2.<ref name=":1" />
=== Cyprus, Czech Republic, Hungary, Korea, and Sweden === Women in [[Cyprus]], including women who are adopting, receive 16 weeks of maternity leave. Nine weeks are mandatory, with the first two beginning two weeks before the expected due date. During this time, women receive a grant which serves as maternity pay. After maternity leave, women can apply to leave work an hour each day with pay for six months to help care for their child.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.mlsi.gov.cy/mlsi/dl/dl.nsf/dmlposting_en/dmlposting_en?OpenDocument|title=Department of Labour - Employment Policy|website=www.mlsi.gov.cy|access-date=2016-12-08}}</ref> In the [[Czech Republic]], women receive 28 weeks of paid maternity leave; the minimum leave is 14 weeks. Families can receive financial support for child care. Women in [[Hungary]] have the options of up to 24 weeks of maternity leave at 70-percent pay or financial support and job insurance to raise the child, with part-time work promoted. In [[Korea]], a woman receives 44 days of maternity leave before the birth and 90 days afterwards. During the first 60 days of the 90-day period, they receive full salary; during the last 30 days, they can receive up to [[South Korean won|₩]]1,350,000. [[Sweden|Swedish]] parents receive 480 days of maternity leave, with 90 days reserved for the father. The first 300 days are at 80-percent of pay, and the remainder is paid at a flat rate.<ref name=":1" />
=== Italy, Latvia, Malta, and Romania === In [[Italy]], women receive 80 percent of their normal earnings for six months.<ref name=":1" /> [[Latvia]]n women are granted 114 days of paid leave, which may be extended based on health complications, the birth of more than one child or if there is more than one child under age two. When they return to work, mothers are allowed time to check on their child (or children).<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.ilo.org/ifpdial/information-resources/national-labour-law-profiles/WCMS_158912/lang--en/index.htm|title=National Labour Law Profile: Latvia|date=2015-09-01|language=en|access-date=2016-12-08}}</ref> [[Malta|Maltese]] women receive 18 weeks of uninterrupted maternity leave. The first 14 weeks are full salary and benefits, and the last four weeks can be covered by the government.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://dier.gov.mt/en/Employment-Conditions/Leave/Pages/Maternity-Leave.aspx|title=Maternity Leave|website=dier.gov.mt|language=en|access-date=2016-12-08}}</ref> In [[Romania]], women have two options: a one-year leave at 75-percent salary, with a bonus when they return to work, or two years at 75 percent without the return bonus.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.lpg-roumanie.ro/en/publications/social/maternity-paternity-leave-in-romania|title=Maternity/Paternity leave in Romania|date=2014-12-19|newspaper=LPG Romania|access-date=2016-12-08}}</ref>
=== Bulgaria, France, and Norway === In [[Bulgaria]] women receive 410 days of maternity leave at 90-percent salary, with 45 days granted before giving birth.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.angloinfo.com/how-to/bulgaria/healthcare/pregnancy-birth/maternity-leave|title=Maternity Leave, Allowance and Benefits - Bulgaria - Angloinfo|newspaper=Angloinfo|access-date=2016-12-08}}</ref> [[France|French]] women are given 16 weeks of paid maternity leave for their first child, and time off increases with subsequent children. The amount paid is based on household income and how many children are already in the family. In [[Norway]], women can choose 49 weeks at 100 percent of salary or 59 weeks at 80 percent.<ref name=":1" />
== {{anchor|Countries Average Pay Rates}}Average pay rates ==
{| class="wikitable floatleft" !Country !Pay rate |- |United Kingdom |30%-39.9% |- |Australia |40%-49.9% |- |Canada |40%-49.9% |- |New Zealand |40%-49.9% |- |Denmark |50%-59.9% |- |Greece |50%-59.9% |- |Switzerland |50%-59.9% |- |Iceland |60%-69.9% |- |Japan |60%-69.9% |- |Turkey |60%-69.9% |- |Slovak Republic |60%-69.9% |- |Cyprus |70%-79.9% |- |Czech Republic |70%-79.9% |- |Hungary |70%-79.9% |- |Korea |70%-79.9% |- |Sweden |70%-79.9% |- |Italy |80%-89.9% |- |Latvia |80%-89.9% |- |Malta |80%-89.9% |- |Romania |80%-89.9% |- |Bulgaria |90%-99.9% |- |France |90%-99.9% |- |Norway |90%-99.9% |}
According to OECD research, 60 percent of countries offering maternity leave do not provide full pay.<ref name=":0" /> The table lists countries offering less than full salary, from lowest to highest.
These pay rates are the average of the paid leave for an individual earning 100 percent of the 2014 national average. In most countries, leave payments are calculated on gross earnings; however, in some—e.g., [[Austria]], [[Chile]], [[France]] and [[Germany]]—payments are based on net earnings (after income-tax and social-security payments). Pay rates in these countries reflect the proportion of net earnings replaced by the relevant payments, and should not be compared directly with pay rates based on gross earnings. Many countries have a variable rate; for example, [[Belgium]] gives women 82% of their salary for the first month. For the remaining three or four months (depending on the number of births) they receive 75 percent, with a cap of €133 per day.
Most OECD countries provide payments replacing over 50 percent of previous earnings, with twelve countries offering average-wage mothers full compensation for the leave. Pay rates are lowest in [[Ireland]] and the [[United Kingdom]], where only about one-third of gross average earnings are replaced by maternity benefits. Despite lengthy paid-leave entitlements, full-rate maternity leave in these countries is only nine weeks in Ireland and twelve in the UK.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.oecd.org/els/soc/PF2_1_Parental_leave_systems.pdf|title=Key Characteristic of Parental Leave Systems|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=|access-date=}}</ref>

'''Mikelis "Mick" Brizga''' was an Australian businessman. He was born in Lithuania in May 1911 and died in Australia in December 2012.
Brizga was a leader in the Australian piano industry. He migrated from his homeland of Latvia to Australia in 1938 and starting working with pianos in the 1940s. His business, '''Brizga Pianos''', sold pianos (new and reconditioned) and was a major supplier of piano parts to Australian piano tuners and repairers.
In 2004, the Piano Tuners and Technicians Guild bestowed a special commendation award for Brizga's outstanding contribution to the piano industry.<ref>{{Citeweb|title=Centenarian who devoted career to the Australian piano industry.|publisher=[[The Age]]|date=14 August 2013|url=http://www.smh.com.au/comment/obituaries/centenarian-who-devoted-career-to-the-australian-piano-industry-20130814-2rwuv.html#ixzz41XT598eu|accessdate=29 February 2016}}</ref>
In his later years, Brizga became well-known for his longevity and vitality. He worked full-time until has late 90s <ref>{{Citeweb|title=After 95 years, this song's for you, Mr Brizga.|publisher=[[The Age]]|date=24 May 2006|url= http://www.theage.com.au/news/national/after-95-years-this-songs-for-you-mr-brizga/2006/05/24/1148150327104.html|accessdate=29 February 2016}}</ref> and continued to work part-time until a few weeks before his death at 101.<ref>{{Citeweb|title=Mick’s in fine tune at 100.|publisher=[[Herald Sun]]|date=24 May 2011|url=http://www.heraldsun.com.au/ipad/in-black-and-white-if-its-too-funny-to-be-true-maybe-its-not/story-fn6bn9st-1226062603340|accessdate=29 February 2016}}</ref><ref>{{Citeweb|title=Customers and music meant everything to the piano man.|publisher=[[Sydney Morning Herald]]|date=19 August 2013|url=http://www.smh.com.au/comment/obituaries/customers-and-music-meant-everything-to-the-piano-man-20130819-2s7kv.html#ixzz41XTTXuUH|accessdate=29 February 2016}}</ref>

'''Nana Kofi Obiri Egyir II''' is a [[Ghanaian people|Ghanaian]] businessman and traditional ruler. He is the [[Sanaahene]] of the [[Cape Coast|Oguaa]] traditional area. He owns the hospitality facility Sanaa Lodge in the [[Central Region (Ghana)|Central Region]] of Ghana. He was appointed to the Council of State by President [[Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo|Nana Addo Dankwa Akuffo-Addo]] in February 2017.<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=http://www.ghananewsagency.org/politics/oguaa-hails-appointment-of-sanaahen-as-council-member-113465|title=Oguaa hails appointment of Sanaahen as Council Member|access-date=2017-12-13}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.atlfmonline.com/home/24-ghana/1724-nana-addo-appoints-georgina-wood-to-council-of-state|title=Nana Addo appoints Georgina Wood to Council of State - atlfmonline|last=Hormeku|first=Rachel|website=www.atlfmonline.com|language=en-gb|access-date=2017-12-13}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.pulse.com.gh/news/politics/full-list-nana-addo-appoints-adjiri-blankson-okudzeto-others-to-council-of-state-id6222727.html|title=Full List: Nana Addo appoints Adjiri Blankson, Okudzeto, others to Council of State|last=Taylor|first=Mildred Europa|access-date=2017-12-13|language=en-US}}</ref> He was once the national treasurer of the Popular Front Party.<ref name=":2" />
== Adult life == Nana Kofi Obiri Egyir II spent much of his working life as a businessman with interests mainly in the Ghanaian hospitality industry.<ref name=":1" /> His business ventures are mostly in the Central Region of Ghana and includes the Sanaa Lodge, a three star hospitality facility close to the [[Elmina Castle]].<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=http://m.peacefmonline.com/pages/local/news/201702/307285.php|title=Be Frank, Get Busy… Nana Tells Council Of State|last=Online|first=Peace FM|website=m.peacefmonline.com|language=en-US|access-date=2017-12-13}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.tripadvisor.com/Hotel_Review-g303866-d1168959-Reviews-Sanaa_Lodge-Cape_Coast_Central_Region.html|title=Sanaa Lodge - UPDATED 2017 Hotel Reviews (Ghana/Cape Coast) - TripAdvisor|website=www.tripadvisor.com|access-date=2017-12-13}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ghanayello.com/company/36643/Sanaa_Lodge_Hotel|title=Sanaa Lodge Hotel|website=GhanaYello|language=en|access-date=2017-12-13}}</ref>
In the 1970s Nana Kofi Obiri Egyir II was elected the national financial secretary of the [[Popular Front Party]].<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":2">{{Cite news|url=https://www.newsghana.com.gh/sanaahen-of-oguaa-traditional-area-joins-council-of-state/|title=Sanaahen Of Oguaa Traditional Area Joins Council of State|date=2017-02-20|work=News Ghana|access-date=2017-12-13|language=en-US}}</ref> He was installed as the Sanaahene - leader of warriors of the traditional area.<ref name=":2" /><ref name=":3">{{Cite news|url=https://www.modernghana.com/news/40539/oguaa-omanhene-says-he-is-frustrated-with-his-people.html|title=Oguaa Omanhene says he is frustrated with his people|work=Modern Ghana|access-date=2017-12-13|language=en-gb}}</ref> As Sanaahene, he aids the [[Omanhene]] of the Oguaa traditional area, [[Osabarimba Kwesi Atta II]], in the performance of his duties as well as presiding over the activities of the [[Asafo|Asafo groups]] in the area.<ref name=":3" />
== Council of State == In February 2017 Nana Kofi Obiri Egyir II was appointed to the council by President [[Nana Akufo-Addo|Nana Akuffo-Addo]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.ghanabusinessnews.com/2017/03/01/nana-siriboe-ii-is-council-of-state-chairman/|title=Nana Siriboe II is Council of State Chairman - Ghana Business News|date=2017-03-01|work=Ghana Business News|access-date=2017-12-12|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://presidency.gov.gh/index.php/2017/02/14/composition-of-the-council-of-state/|title=Composition of The Council Of State – The Presidency, Republic of Ghana|website=presidency.gov.gh|language=en-US|access-date=2017-12-12}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://ghanapa.com/okudzeto-13-others-appointed-as-council-of-state/|title=Okudzeto, 13 others appointed as Council of State|work=GhanaPa.com - The Goodness News Portal|access-date=2017-12-13|language=en-GB}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.ghanaweb.com/GhanaHomePage/business/Okudzeto-13-others-appointed-by-Akufo-Addo-to-Council-of-State-510126|title=Okudzeto, 13 others appointed by Akufo-Addo to Council of State|website=www.ghanaweb.com|language=en|access-date=2017-12-13}}</ref> During the swearing-in ceremony held at The Flagstaff House, President Akuffo-Addo entreated the council to advise him well with the view to always propel Ghana to greater heights.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://dailyguideafrica.com/council-state-elects-chairman/nana-otuo-siriboe-ii/|title=Nana Otuo Siriboe II - Daily Guide Africa|website=dailyguideafrica.com|language=en-US|access-date=2017-12-12}}</ref> During the handing over ceremony of the sixth session of the council to the seventh, the outgoing council chair, [[John S. Nabila|Naa Prof. John S. Nabila]], advised the new house to give their best counsel to the new government to ensure that the country and all its citizens would live in prosperity and peace.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.peacefmonline.com/pages/local/social/201702/307237.php?storyid=100&|title=Nana Otuo Siriboe II Elected Chairman of the Council of State|last=Online|first=Peace FM|access-date=2017-12-14}}</ref> The appointment of Nana Kofi Obiri Egyir II was gladly received by the people of the Central Region who also pledged their support for him.<ref name=":0" /> Some believed that his vast experience in the business world as well as in Ghanaian traditional rule would help the council greatly.<ref name=":0" />

'''Olle Johan Eriksen''' (12 August 1923 – 26 March 1999) was a Norwegian politician for the [[Conservative Party of Norway|Conservative Party]]. He was born in [[Haugesund]]. Eriksen, who belonged to [[Rogaland]], was never elected directly to the [[Storting|Norwegian Parliament]] but served as a deputy representative in the periods 1969–1973 and 1973–1977. During the first term he was brought in as a replacement representative for [[Egil Endresen]], who became appointed to the Cabinet in 1970. Eriksen sat as a regular representative until March 1971, when the cabinet of which Endresen was a part was dissolved, allowing him to return to his seat in Parliament. On the local level Eriksen held various positions in [[Haugesund]] [[municipal council (Norway)|municipal council]] between 1963 and 1987, as well as being a deputy member from 1991 to his death in 1999. He served as deputy mayor in 1966–1967 and 1975–1977, and mayor in 1970–1971, 1974–1975, 1978–1979 and 1979–1983. During most of this time he was also a member of Rogaland county council. Outside politics he was a local businessman. He was also active in [[tennis]]. ==References== *{{stortingetbio|OLER}}

In [[economics]], '''rationalization''' is an attempt to change a pre-existing [[ad hoc]] [[workflow]] into one that is based on a set of published rules. There is a tendency in modern times to quantify experience, [[knowledge economy|knowledge]], and [[Labour (economics)|work]]. Means–end (goal-oriented) rationality is used to precisely calculate that which is necessary to attain a goal. Its effectiveness varies with the enthusiasm of the workers for the changes being made, the skill with which management applies the rules, and the degree to which the rules fit the job.
Rationalization aims at an efficiency increase by better use of existing possibilities: A same effect can with fewer means, or with same means to be obtained. In the industry thereby frequently the replacement of manpower is designated by machines (rationalization investment). It is the reasonable, appropriate organization of operational conditions under changing conditions to increase with the goal, productivity and economy.
Julien Freund defines rationalization as "the organization of life through a division and coordination of activities on the basis of exact study of men's relations with each other, with their tools and their environment, for the purpose of achieving greater efficiency and productivity".<ref name="Freund">Freund, Julien, 1968. ''The Sociology of Max Weber''. New York: Vintage Books.</ref>
The rationalization process is the practical application of knowledge to achieve a desired end. Its purpose is to bring about [[economic efficiency|efficiency]], coordination, and control of the [[natural environment|natural]] and [[social environment]]. It is a product of "scientific specialization and technical differentiation" that seems to be a characteristic of [[Western culture]].<ref name="Freund"/> Rationalization is the guiding principle behind [[bureaucracy]] and the increasing [[division of labour|division of labor]], and has led to an increase in both the production and distribution of [[goods and services]]. It is also associated with [[secularization]] without its more positive component of [[humanism]], with depersonalization and with oppressive routine.
Increasingly, human behavior is to be guided by observation, experiment, and reason (''[[Instrumental action|zweckrational]]'').<ref name="Elwell">Elwell, Frank W., 1999. ''Industrializing America: Understanding Contemporary Society through Classical Sociological Analysis''. West Port, Connecticut: Praeger.</ref> Change in human character is expected to be part of the process; rationalization and bureaucratization promote efficiency, and [[economic materialism|materialism]], both of which are subsumed under [[Max Weber|Weber]]'s concept of ''zweckrational''.
==See also== *[[Labour (economics)|Labor (economics)]] *[[Managerial economics]] *[[Max Weber]] *[[Scientific management]]

{{redirect|Summer job|other uses|Summer job (disambiguation)}} A '''seasonal industry''' is activity within an economic [[List of recognized economic sectors|sector]] in which the majority of operations take place during only part of the year, usually within a period of half a year or less.<ref>{{cite book|title=Assembly Bills, Original and Amended|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=VDhRAQAAMAAJ&pg=PA50-IA67|pages=50–}}</ref>
In some cases, as with [[agriculture]], this limitation may relate to [[climate]] or other forces of nature. In others, the seasonality may relate to annual variations in human activity (for example, [[tourism]], [[restaurant]]s, some forms of [[manufacturing]]).
Seasonal industries often feature large swings in labor force size, and in many cases, precipitate mass [[Migrant worker|migrations of workers]].
In those countries that provide them, [[unemployment benefit]]s may be affected by a worker's seasonal status. That is, in certain cases, a seasonal worker may not be considered "[[unemployed]]" during the off-season for the sake of benefits or aggregated statistics,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.coworkforce.com/uib/regulation/default.asp?section=seasonal|title=Colorado Workforce Regulations (example)|accessdate=2006-08-23 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20060515190615/http://www.coworkforce.com/uib/regulation/default.asp?section=seasonal <!-- Bot retrieved archive --> |archivedate = 2006-05-15}}</ref> despite being functionally inactive.

[[Image:1925 Poster for the Labour Olympiad in Frankfurt.jpg|thumb|250px|1925 Poster for the Workers' Olympiad in Frankfurt]] '''Socialist Workers' Sport International''' ({{lang-de|Sozialistische Arbeitersport Internationale}}, SASI) was an international [[socialist]] sporting organisation, based in [[Lucerne]]. It was founded in 1920, and consisted of six national federations (with a combined membership of about one million) at the time of its foundation. Initially it was known as '''International Association for Sports and Physical Culture'''. Informally it was known as the '''Lucerne Sport International'''. It adopted the name SASI in 1926.Kidd, Bruce. The Struggle for Canadian Sport. Toronto: University of Toronto Press, 1996. p. 153 The [[Austro-Marxism|Austro-Marxist]] [[Julius Deutsch]] was the president of SASI. [[International Labour Sports Federation]] (CSIT) was established in 1946 as the successor of SASI.[[Arnd Krüger]] & [[James Riordan]] (eds.) (1996). ''The Story of Worker Sport.'' Champaign, IL: Human Kinetics. {{ISBN|978-0873228749}}; Halevi Olin (ed.) (2013). ''Sport, Peace and Development. International Worker Sport. 1913 - 2013.'' Wien: CSIT {{ISBN|978-3-9503593-1-2}} ==Foundation== An international meeting of workers sports associations had been held in [[Ghent]], [[Belgium]], in 1913. However, the [[First World War]] put the build-up of an international workers' sport organisation on hold. After the war two Belgians, Gaston Bridoux and Jules Devlieger, took initiative to revive the cooperation. Preparatory meetings were held in [[Seraing]], [[Belgium]] in 1919 and in [[Paris]], [[France]], during Easter 1920. The founding congress of the international took place in Lucerne September 13-September 14, 1920. During the foundation, the French and Belgian delegations urged that the word 'Socialist' be omitted from the name of the organisation, in order to attract a broader following.Steinberg, David A.. ''[https://www.jstor.org/stable/260115 The Workers' Sport Internationals 1920–28]'', in ''Journal of Contemporary History'', Vol. 13, No. 2, Special Issue: Workers' Culture (Apr., 1978), pp. 233–251 ==Politics== The organisation upheld a policy of neutrality towards party organisations, a policy inherited from the German workers' sports movement (which tried to steer away from the fractional conflicts between the German socialists). This policy was however challenged by the communists, which claimed that the workers' sport movement could not abstain from taking part in revolutionary struggle. In 1921, the third congress of the [[Communist International]] decided to form a parallel sport international. In August 1921, the [[Sportintern]] was founded. [[Sportintern]] launched fierce political attacks against the Lucerne international. Its Czechoslovak section had suffered a split in July 1921, as the communists deserted it. At the second congress of the Lucerne International, held in Leipzig 1922, the French delegation argued in favour of unification between the two Internationals. This policy was not supported by the congress. The following year, the French affiliate FST decided to shift its membership to [[Sportintern]]. Ahead of the 1925 Workers Olympiad, the [[Sportintern]] appealed to the Lucerne International that four [[Sportintern]] delegations (France, Soviet Union, Norway, Czechoslovakia) should be allowed to participate. Discussions lingered on within the Lucerne International, but after communist sportsmen had made a public protest at a German Workers Sports Festival in [[Karlovy Vary|Karlsbad]] in 1924, it was decided that the [[Sportintern]] would be barred from the Workers Olympiad. Likewise SASI barred its affiliates for participating in the 1928 [[Spartakiad]] organised by [[Sportintern]]. Politically, SASI was supported by the [[International Federation of Trade Unions]] and the [[Labour and Socialist International]].http://ci.nii.ac.jp/naid/110001136801/ ==Workers' Olympiads== The main activity of SASI was the organizing of the [[International Workers' Olympiads]], portrayed as a socialist alternative to the '[[bourgeois]]' [[Olympics]]. At the Workers Olympiads only the [[red flag (politics)|red flag]] was used, rather than national flags. *The [[1925 Workers' Summer Olympiad|first Workers' Olympiad]] was held in [[Frankfurt am Main]], [[Germany]], in 1925. There were around 150,000 spectators. A world record was broken in the 100 meter women's relay race. The summer Workers Olympiad had been preceded by [[1925 Workers' Winter Olympiad|winter games]] the same year, in [[Schreiberhau]], in which twelve national delegations had participated. *The [[1931 Workers' Summer Olympiad|second Workers' Olympiad]] was held in [[Vienna]], [[Austria]], in 1931. 80,000 athletes took part in the games, which had around 250,000 spectators. The games were larger than the [[1932 Los Angeles Olympics]], both in number of participants and spectators.http://www.vcn.bc.ca/outlook/library/articles/jewsontheleft/p05SocialistSports.htm *A [[1931 Workers' Winter Olympiad|winter Workers' Olympiad]] was held in [[Mürzzuschlag]], [[Austria]], in 1931. Like the summer event, the winter Workers Olympiad was larger (in number of participants and spectators) than the [[1932 Lake Placid Olympics]]. *The [[1937 Workers' Summer Olympiad|third Workers' Olympiad]] was held in [[Antwerp]], [[Belgium]] in 1937. For the first time, non-SASI organisations could send delegates. A delegation from the [[Soviet Union]] took part, and won the football final. Around 50,000 people watched the final day of the Workers Olympiad, and 200 000 took part in the closing rally. A [[1937 Workers' Winter Olympiad|winter Workers Olympics]] were held in [[Janské Lázně]], [[Czechoslovakia]]. *A [[1943 Workers' Summer Olympiad|fourth Workers' Olympiad]] was planned to be held in [[Helsinki]], [[Finland]] in 1943, but never materialized.Wheeler, Robert F.. ''[https://www.jstor.org/stable/260113 Organized Sport and Organized Labour: The Workers' Sports Movement]'', in ''Journal of Contemporary History'', Vol. 13, No. 2, Special Issue: Workers' Culture (Apr., 1978), pp. 191–210{{cite web |year=2008 |url = http://www.iisg.nl/collections/olympiads/intro.php|title = A Dozen Pictures of the Labour Olympiads|publisher = [[International Institute of Social History]]| accessdate = 2008-09-29 | last=Eric de Ruijter |quote=}} ==Affiliates (incomplete list)== *[[BWSA|British Workers' Sports Association]]http://www.archiveshub.ac.uk/news/brwsa.html *[[Morgnshtern]] (a [[Jew]]ish socialist sport federation in [[Poland]], joined the SASI as its 'Jewish section', at its 1929 congress in [[Prague]])Kugelmass, Jack. ''Jews, Sports, and the Rites of Citizenship''. {{BLP sources|date=May 2018}} {{notability|Biographies|date=May 2018}} {{Infobox person | name = Susan Oguya | image = | image_size = | caption = | birth_date = {{Birth year and age|1987}} | birth_place = [[Kenya]] | death_date = | death_place = | alma_mater ='''[[Strathmore University]]'''

'''[[Domus Academy]]'''
{{small|([[Master of Design]])}} | occupation = [[Designer]] | years_active = 2009 — present | nationality = Kenyan | ethnicity = | citizenship = Kenyan | residence = | known_for = Design | networth = | home_town = | title = Founder & Former [[chief operating officer|COO]] of [https://www.mfarm.co.ke/ MFarm Kenya Limited] | spouse = | religion = }} '''Susan Eve Oguya Kutalek''', commonly known as '''Susan Oguya''', is a [[businesswoman]], [[designer]] and [[entrepreneur]] in [[Kenya]]. She is the co-founder and former [[chief operating officer]] of [[MFarm Kenya Limited]], an internet-based organisation that helps farmers find the best farm implements, seeds and access to weather reports and market information. Since August 2015, she works as a senior designer at [[Dalberg Global Development Advisors]], based in [[New York City]].{{cite web|date=11 September 2017 |url=https://www.carnegiecouncil.org/people/susan-oguya |location=New York City | accessdate=10 November 2017 |publisher=Carnegiecouncil.org (Carnegie Council) |title=Susan Eve Oguya: Dalberg Design Impact Group; Co-Founder, MFarm Kenya Limited | author=Carnegie Council}} ==Background and education== She was born in the western part of Kenya in 1987. She attended Kenyan schools for her pre-university studies. She was exposed to computers when one of her uncles, who was studying in the capital city of [[Nairobi]], came home with his desktop during the vacations. Later, her uncle bought her a desktop of her own. She decided to study IT at university.{{cn|date=May 2018}} In 2010, she completed a four-year undergraduate course, graduating from [[Strathmore University]], with a [[Bachelor of Science]], majoring in Business Information Technology.{{cn|date=May 2018}} In 2013 she was admitted to the [[Università Cattolica del Sacro Cuore]] (Catholic University of the Sacred Heart), in [[Milan, Italy]]. After one year, she graduated with a [[Master of Business Administration]]. From there, she joined [[Domus Academy]], also in Milan, where she studied design, graduating in 2015 with a [[Master of Design]] degree, majoring in Human Computer Interaction.{{cn|date=May 2018}} ==Career== During her final year of undergraduate study, she worked as a Microsoft Student Partner. During the same time frame, she concurrently worked in the Student Enterprise Program, where she worked with stakeholders to produce educational, marketing and promotional material, in her capacity as Communication and Publicity Manager.{{cn|date=May 2018}} She worked briefly as a [[software developer]] for [[Safaricom]], then as a research assistant at ''iHub Nairobi'', a software development enterprise, before settling down at Akirachix,{{cite web| accessdate=10 November 2017 |url=https://www.npr.org/sections/alltechconsidered/2012/12/24/167961947/kenyan-women-create-their-own-geek-cuture |title=Kenyan Women Create Their Own 'Geek Culture'|first=Gregory | last=Warner |publisher=[[National Public Radio]] (NPR) |date=24 December 2012 |location=Washington, DC}} where she worked for one and half years as a training manager. There she trained young women ages 18 to 25 years in life skills and basic and mid-level computer competencies, including programming. A total of 30 women were trained from April 2010 until October 2011.{{cn|date=May 2018}} In late 2010, she and two other collaborators co-founded MFarm Kenya Limited, with Oguya working as [[chief technology officer]], responsible for coding, testing and troubleshooting the [[mobile app]], from October 2010 until July 2012. She then spent the next two years developing and strengthening the business application of the app, by interacting with clients, funders, business partners and coders, in her capacity as [[Chief Operating Officer]] of MFarm Kenya Limited. She left the employment of MFarm in August 2014.{{cn|date=May 2018}} As of December 2012, the company had 18 full-time employees and over 7,000 clients regionally. In 2015 when she completed graduate school in Italy, she relocated to the [[United States]], working as a senior designer at Dalberg Global Development Advisors, based in New York, New York since August 2015.{{cn|date=May 2018}} ==See also== *[[Jamila Abbas]] *[[Ada Osakwe]] *[[Amira Elmissiry]] *[[Tebogo Mashego]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[https://www.mfarm.co.ke/ Website of MFarm Kenya Limited] {{DEFAULTSORT:Oguya, Susan}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:1987 births]] [[Category:Kenyan businesspeople]] [[Category:Domus Academy alumni]] [[Category:Università Cattolica del Sacro Cuore alumni]] [[Category:Kenyan women in business]] [[Category:21st-century businesswomen]] [[Category:Strathmore University alumni]] [[Category:Kenyan business executives]] [[Category:Kenyan women business executives]] [[Category:People from Nairobi]]

'''The British-Swiss Chamber of Commerce (BSCC)''' was founded in 1920 and is an independent [[Non-profit organization|not-for-profit organisation]] with more than 500 Members. It promotes [[business relations]] between [[Switzerland]], [[Liechtenstein]] and the [[United Kingdom|UK]]. The Chamber provides a network and platform for business people to facilitate dialogue and change. The BSCC offers an open forum for debate, networking and access to key decision makers and influencers from all sectors and nationalities.
The BSCC is composed of Corporate, SME and Individual Members that are a part of 4 Membership Categories: Network, Promote, Lead and Influence. BSCC Members represent the majority of business sectors, including Commodities & Energy, Consumer goods & Retail, Financials, Human Capital, Industrial & Manufacturing, Insurance, Life Sciences & Pharma, Luxury, Professional Services, Real Estate, Technology and Travel & Culture.
Represented by Geographically defined Chapters, the BSCC is active in [[Basel]], [[Berne]], [[Central Switzerland]], [[Geneva]], Liechtenstein, [[Ticino]], UK and [[Zurich]]. The BSCC has Special Interest Groups covering Public Affairs and Legal and Tax. Across all Chapters the BSCC organizes around 100 events each year featuring C-suite speakers and offering trainings, workshops, panel discussions, business breakfasts and lunches, after work and gala events for members and non-members.
== Organisation == An elected President and a Secretary General head up the organisation. Both the Swiss Ambassador in [[London]] and the British Ambassador in Bern are Honorary Presidents.
The BSCC Team is made up of more than 100 Individuals in Switzerland and the UK, of whom the majority support the BSCC on a voluntarily basis. Most of their volunteers are representatives of member companies and are active in the Council, Executive Board, Chapter Committees, Public Affairs Commission (PAC) and Task Force Europe.
• Councillors review the executive operations and constitute the governing body of the BSCC • The Executive Board oversees operational matters and drives BSCC strategy • Chapter Committee Members are the BSCC's local brand ambassadors and provide ideas for chapter event programmes • The Public Affairs Commission identifies political and economic issues of bilateral interest • Task Force Europe provides insight on relevant European trends and developments
In 2016 Anne-Marie de Weck, took over the Presidency of the BSCC. James Woodeson joined the BSCC as Secretary General in 2017.
== Special Interest Groups ==
The Public Affairs Commission (PAC) serves as a business platform for furthering the understanding of political and economic issues of common interest to the British and Swiss business communities. On an annual basis, PAC organises Public Affairs Dinners in Berne and Westminster to encourage dialogue between members, parliamentarians and the broader business world.
The remit of the Task Force Europe is to examine the similarities and differences in the way Switzerland and the UK approach European issues. The Task Force operates as an independent think tank that provides BSCC members with an analytical perspective on topical themes and political developments.
== COBCOE == The BSCC is a member of [[COBCOE]], (Council of British Chambers of Commerce in Europe). Founded in 1973, COBCOE is an independent non-profit organisation representing 40 British [[Chamber of commerce|chambers of commerce]] in 37 countries across [[Europe]]. Acting as an [[umbrella organisation]], they work with their member chambers to advance international trade and business with the United Kingdom.

'''Thomas Michael Burke''', [[Order of St Michael and St George|CMG]] (30 June 1870 – 16 February 1949) was an Australian businessman and philanthropist.
Burke was born at Norval, near [[Ararat, Victoria|Ararat]] in [[Victoria (Australia)|Victoria]], to [[Dublin]]-born miner William Marcus Burke and [[Aberdeen]]-born Mary Ann, ''née'' Florence. He attended Norval State School and Ararat High School before becoming a railway clerk in 1887, overseeing first [[Southern Cross railway station|Spencer Street station]] and then [[Ararat railway station|Ararat]] from 1892. On 25 July 1898 he married Margaret Duggan Brady at St Mary's Catholic Church at Ararat. He was involved in the later stages of the [[Australian Federation|Federation]] movement as president of the local branch of the Australian Natives' Association (ANA) and vice-president (1900–01) and chief president (1902–03) of the Victorian ANA.<ref name=adb>{{Cite web | last = Hannan | first = Tony | authorlink = | coauthors = | title = Burke, Thomas Michael (1870-1949) | work = [[Australian Dictionary of Biography]] | publisher = [[Australian National University]] | date = 1979 | url = http://adb.anu.edu.au/biography/burke-thomas-michael-5430 | format = | doi = | accessdate = 12 November 2011}}</ref>
Burke was appointed secretary of the Civil Service Co-operative Society of Victoria in March 1902 and was involved in the railway workers' clash with the [[William Irvine (Australian politician)|Irvine]] government; later that year he resigned from the railways and founded the Civil Service Co-operative Store in [[Flinders Street, Melbourne|Flinders Street]]. An ardent [[protectionist]], he contested the [[Australian federal election, 1914|1914 federal election]] as the [[Australian Labor Party|Labor]] candidate for [[Division of Corangamite|Corangamite]] but was defeated. He sold the Co-operative Store in 1915 and entered the real estate business, and by 1924 was also involved in finance and investment, with offices in [[Sydney]], [[Newcastle, New South Wales|Newcastle]], [[Brisbane]], [[Adelaide]] and various country centres.<ref name=adb/>
Burke survived the [[Great Depression|Depression]] and during the 1930s his company, T. M. Burke Pty Ltd, had established branches in [[Auckland]], [[Singapore]] and [[London]]. He retired from everyday management of the business in May 1936, but remained chairman of directors. He held several other positions in addition to his business interests, serving as president of the Breeders, Owners and Trainers' Association of Victoria (as an avid [[horse racing|horse racer]]), member (1931–49) and chairman (1936–39, 1944–45) of the Victorian Hospitals and Charities Board, member of the Victorian Council of the [[Australian Red Cross]], and consul for [[Poland]] (1933–49). He also gave financial support to the Melbourne University Conservatorium Symphony Orchestra, and donated both land and money to the [[Catholic Church]]; he was inaugural national chairman of the Knights of the Southern Cross, accepted a chalice from [[Pope Pius XI]] on behalf of Australian Catholic businessman, and lobbied for state aid to Catholic schools.<ref name=adb/>
Appointed [[Companion of the Order of St Michael and St George]] in 1942, Burke retired to [[Armadale, Victoria|Armadale]]. He died of [[cancer]] in 1949.<ref name=adb/>

{{Use dmy dates|date=September 2017}} {{Use British English|date=September 2017}} '''Trevor Boyns''' (born 1953) is a British business historian and Professor of Accounting & Business History at the [[Cardiff University]], known for his work in the field of the [[history of accountancy]]<ref>Hoskin, Keith W., and Richard H. Macve. "[http://grammatikhilfe.com/accounting/pdf/MacveAhjpub.pdf Knowing more as knowing less? Alternative histories of cost and management accounting in the US and the UK] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141110001256/http://grammatikhilfe.com/accounting/pdf/MacveAhjpub.pdf |date=10 November 2014 }}." The Accounting Historians Journal (2000): 91-149.</ref> and [[business history]].<ref>Carnegie, Garry D., and Christopher J. Napier. "Critical and interpretive histories: insights into accounting’s present and future through its past." ''Accounting, Auditing & Accountability Journal'' 9.3 (1996): 7-39.</ref>
== Biography ==
Boyns obtained his [[first class degree]] in mathematics and economics in 1974 from the [[University of Warwick]], and his PhD in econometric history in 1982 from the [[University of Wales]]<ref name="bc 2014">[http://business.cardiff.ac.uk/people/staff/trevor-boyns Professor Trevor Boyns, Professor of Accounting & Business History] at ''business.cardiff.ac.uk.'' Accessed 11.2014.</ref> with the thesis, entitled "Labour productivity in the British coal industry, 1874-1913."
Boyns spends his academic career at the Cardiff University, where he started in 1976 as tutorial fellow. In 1978 he was appointed lecturer, in 1997 senior lecturer and in 2004 Professor of Accounting & Business History. Nowadays in 2014 he is also Director of Undergraduate Programmes for Economics. He initially focussed his research on the economic and business history of the British coal industry, particularly about the [[South Wales Coalfield]] but in the 1990s started focussing his research on the [[history of accountancy]].<ref name="bc 2014"/>
Boyns has been President of the Association of Business Historians, and founding editor or the ''Accounting, Business & Financial History.''<ref>Geoffrey Jones, Jonathan Zeitlin (2008). ''The Oxford Handbook of Business History.'' p. xii.</ref>
== Selected publications == * Trevor Boyns, Malcolm Anderson, J. R. Edwards (eds.). ''British Cost Accounting, 1887-1952: Contemporary Essays from the Accounting literature.'' 1996/2014 * Boyns, Trevor, John Richard Edwards, and Marc Nikitin. ''The birth of industrial accounting in France and Britain.'' Taylor & Francis, 1997/2013. * Trevor Boyns, J. R. Edwards. ''A History of Management Accounting: The British Experience.'' 2012.
Articles, a selection: * Edwards, John Richard, and Trevor Boyns. "Industrial organization and accounting innovation: charcoal ironmaking in England 1690–1783." ''Management Accounting Research'' 3.2 (1992): 151-169. * Edwards, John Richard, Trevor Boyns, and Malcolm Anderson. "British cost accounting development: continuity and change." ''The Accounting Historians Journal'' (1995): 1-41. * Boyns, Trevor, and John Richard Edwards. "The development of accounting in mid-nineteenth century Britain: a non-disciplinary view." Accounting, Auditing & Accountability Journal 9.3 (1996): 40-60. * Boyns, Trevor, and John Richard Edwards. "Cost and management accounting in early Victorian Britain: a Chandleresque analysis?." ''Management Accounting Research'' 8.1 (1997): 19-46. * Boyns, Trevor, and John Richard Edwards. "The Construction of Cost Accounting Systems in Britain to 1900: The Case of the Coal, Iron and Steel Industries 1." ''Business History'' 39.3 (1997): 1-29. * Boyns, Trevor, and John Richard Edwards. "[https://www.researchgate.net/publication/229175217_The_Development_of_Cost_and_Management_Accounting_in_Britain/file/5046352d661a673f98.pdf The development of cost and management accounting in Britain]." ''Handbooks of Management Accounting Research'' 2 (2006): 969-1034.
